comments:
Build 20020502

- new workspace
- turned autobuild off
- loaded org.eclipse.ui from source
- imported all other plugins from binary
- created new launch config for target eclipse
- hit Debug in launch config dialog
- it built org.eclipse.ui
- got the following errors
- (the target came up anyway)

The problem here appears to be the fact that the JDIDebugPlugin was somehow 
shutdown prematurely.

Isn't plugin startup and shutdown managed by the workbench?

The problem looks like plug-in startup did not complete properly. The NPE is 
caused by the "org.eclipse.jdt.debug.core" plug-in not starting up. The 
question is why were there problems loading the "DisplayView" class:

(org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.DelegatingURLClassLoader$DelegatingLoaderExcepti
on: Plugin org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui activation failed while loading class 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.display.DisplayView)

Jared, please try to reproduce this problem with exact steps Nick shows. Do not 
open the java perspective to do this (if possible). It looks like we could get 
all the way to pressing the debug button without loading JDT UI or JDT Debug 
UI.
*** Bug 15402 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Cannot reproduce.

Also, I don't understand how your (Darin's) scenario of the plugin never 
getting loaded is possible. Both Nick and Ryan were in the Java perspective 
when this happened so JDT UI had to be loaded. JDT UI requires 
JDIDebugPlugin, so it should have also been loaded and started up.

The top stack trace here violates my understanding of how our class loader 
is supposed to behave - either I'm misinformed or there is a class loader 
bug.

JDIDebugUIPlugin requires the JDIDebugPlugin. I thought that this meant 
JDIDebugPlugin's startup() method was guaranteed to be called before 
JDIDebugUIPlugin's startup(). However, the stack trace comes out of 
JDIDebugUIPlugin#startup() and gets into the JDIDebugPlugin before the 
startup() method is called.

So: 
((<JDIDebugPlugin hadn't been loaded> && (<I don't understand the class 
loader> || <the class loader is broken>)) || <JDIDebugPlugin was shutdown 
prematurely>)

Nick, are you sure there weren't any relevant errors before these stack traces?

This would make a lot more sense if the JDIDebugPlugin had blown up during its 
startup some time earlier.

I didn't see any other errors.
Note that this was a new install of 0502 as well.
Also, your assumption is correct: I was in the Java perspective.

Can either of you (Nick or Ryan) reproduce this? 

Has it happened more than once?

It happened to me on two seperate occasions, although I couldn't intentionally 
reproduce the problem after restarting Eclipse.
I just tried again and was unable to reproduce it.
Nick & Ryan, what VMs are you using?

Both when I encountered it first, and when I was unable to reproduce it 
yesterday, I was running the IBM JDK 1.3.1 recently posted to the downloads 
page (the one with the April timestamp).

Jed and John tracked this down to a nasty multi-threaded plugin startup timing 
problem. We had a bad storm here and lost power so the update couldn't be 
posted here. Expect more information from Jed shortly.

Following the steps Nick gave with the plugin activation tracing turned on I got
the following trace.  Notice at the end that the plugin activation for
org.eclipse.jdt.debug and org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui are not nested.  If plugin
activation was occuring in a single thread, then the activations should have
been nested.

As a fix I would suggest that the JDIDebugPlugin#startup() method be removed. 
The two fields it initializes could be lazily created if accessors for them were
introduced.  This is a much safer approach than attempting to solve the
multi-threaded startup issue.

The code in the JDIDebugPlugin#startup() method must be run at startup.

However, we can add accessors to the fields that are used by other methods and 
do some (ugly) synchronization checks to defend against this problem.

Fixed. Added accessor reference to the HCR manager as well as synchronization.

Also, heavily refactored JavaDebugOptionsManager to do a lot less work during 
startup.
Please verify.
Verified.
